Conceptual Question:

title: Why is it so hard to cure cancer? - Kyuson Yun

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary reason why cancer is difficult to cure?

options.label: A
options.text: Cancer cells are highly adaptable and can easily be destroyed by the immune system.

options.label: C
options.text: Cancer cells can accumulate mutations that allow them to grow unchecked and metastasize.

options.label: D
options.text: Cancer cells are not present in the human body.

multiple-choice.question: What is the term for the process by which cancer cells in a tumor develop distinct genetic mutations, giving rise to unique subclones?
What is the main challenge in developing new cancer treatments using cell lines grown in labs from cultures of human tumors?

options.label: A
options.text: The cell lines are too complex.

options.label: B
options.text: The cell lines are too simple.

options.label: C
options.text: The cell lines lack much of the complexity of a tumor in an actual living organism.

options.label: D
options.text: The cell lines are not relevant to real patients.

multiple-choice.question: What is the term for the process by which a tumor is a dynamic interconnected ecosystem where cancer cells constantly communicate with each other and with healthy cells nearby?
What are the rare cancer cells that seem to have special properties that make them resistant to chemotherapy and radiation?
What is the main challenge in targeting cancer stem cells?

options.label: B
options.text: They are highly resistant to chemotherapy and radiation.

options.label: C
options.text: They are too easy to target.

options.label: D
options.text: They are not present in the tumor.

multiple-choice.question: What is the term for the process by which cancer cells adjust their molecular and cellular characteristics to survive under stress, such as radiation or chemotherapy?
What is the main reason why cancer treatments are not 100% effective 100% of the time?

options.label: A
options.text: Cancer cells can accumulate mutations that allow them to grow unchecked and metastasize.

options.label: C
options.text: Cancer cells are not present in the tumor.

multiple-choice.question: What is the term for the phenomenon where aggressive brain tumors can have multiple populations of slightly different cancerous cells?
What is the main challenge in developing new cancer treatments that can adjust as the cancer changes?

options.label: D
options.text: We need to find experimental systems that match the complexity of cancer.

title: Why Facts Don't Convince People (and what you can do about it)

multiple-choice.question: Why do humans often make decisions based on emotions rather than facts?

options.label: A
options.text: Because humans have a natural instinct to be rational.

options.label: B
options.text: Because the human brain evolved to help us survive, not necessarily to be factually accurate.

options.label: C
options.text: Because humans are influenced by external factors such as media and politics.

options.label: D
options.text: Because humans are not intelligent enough to make rational decisions.

multiple-choice.question: What happens when people encounter facts that contradict their current beliefs?

options.label: A
options.text: They become more confident in their original ideas.

options.label: B
options.text: They become less confident in their original ideas.

options.label: D
options.text: They become more open-minded and willing to consider alternative perspectives.

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary problem with trying to change people's minds with facts?

options.label: A
options.text: It is an ineffective way to change people's minds.

options.label: B
options.text: It leads to further polarization and division.

options.label: C

options.text: The pyramids were built by the Egyptians through trial and error

options.label: C
options.text: The pyramids were built by the pharaohs as a symbol of their power

options.label: D
options.text: The pyramids were built as a way to honor the gods

multiple-choice.question: What is the author's message at the end of the transcript?

options.label: A
options.text: The pyramids are a mystery that will never be solved

options.label: B
options.text: The pyramids are a testament to the ingenuity of the Egyptians

options.label: C
options.text: The pyramids are a reminder of the importance of science and technology

options.label: D
options.text: The pyramids are a symbol of the power of the pharaohs

title: The science of smog - Kim Preshoff

multiple-choice.question: What term is used to describe the thick gray haze that covered cities such as London, Glasgow, and Edinburgh?
What were the primary culprits identified by chemist Arie Haagen-Smit as the cause of the smog that plagued Los Angeles in 1943?

options.label: A
options.text: Volatile organic compounds (VOCs) and nitrogen oxides

multiple-choice.question: What are the secondary pollutants produced by the reaction of VOCs and nitrogen oxides with sunlight?

options.label: A
options.text: PANs and tropospheric, or ground-level, ozone

multiple-choice.question: What phenomenon contributes to smog formation by trapping a pollution-filled layer of air near the Earth's surface?

options.label: A
options.text: A layer of cool air above a pollution-filled layer of air

multiple-choice.question: Which city is an example of a location that is vulnerable to smog due to its geography?
What are the main effects of smog on the respiratory system?

options.label: A
options.text: It can cause respiratory infections like bronchitis

options.label: B
options.text: It can exacerbate conditions like asthma and emphysema

options.label: C
options.text: It can irritate the eyes, nose, and throat

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary purpose of the Clean Air Act of 1956?

options.label: A
options.text: To regulate vehicle emissions and gas content in the US

options.label: B
options.text: To ban burning coal in certain areas of the city

multiple-choice.question: Which countries depend on coal for energy and experience high levels of industrial smog?
What are the potential effects of exposure to smog in pregnant women?
What is one potential solution to reduce smog levels in cities?

options.label: A
options.text: Banning cars from driving for days at a time

options.label: B
options.text: Considering a shift to mass transit and away from fossil fuels

multiple-choice.question: What is the term used to describe the thick, yellowish haze that forms when VOCs and nitrogen oxides react with sunlight?
Which city is an example of a location that is vulnerable to smog due to its geography and weather conditions?
What is the main cause of the Great Smog of London in 1952?
What are the effects of exposure to smog on young children and older people?

options.label: A
options.text: It can cause respiratory infections like bronchitis

options.label: B
options.text: It can exacerbate conditions like asthma and emphysema

options.label: C
options.text: It can irritate the eyes, nose, and throat

multiple-choice.question: What are the secondary pollutants found in photochemical smog that can damage and weaken crops?

options.label: A
options.text: PANs and tropospheric, or ground-level, ozone

multiple-choice.question: What is the term used to describe the phenomenon where a pollution-filled layer of air is trapped near the Earth's surface by a slightly warmer layer above?

options.label: B
options.text: A layer of cool air above a pollution-filled layer of air

multiple-choice.question: What is the main effect of smog on crops?

options.label: A
options.text: It can cause respiratory infections in plants

options.label: B
options.text: It can damage and weaken crops

multiple-choice.question: What is the term used to describe the shift away from fossil fuels and towards mass transit as a solution to reduce smog levels in cities?

options.label: B
options.text: Considering a shift to mass transit and away from fossil fuels

multiple-choice.question: Which city's geography and weather conditions make it particularly vulnerable to smog?
What is the primary purpose of the Clean Air Act of 1956 in relation to smog?

options.label: A
options.text: To regulate vehicle emissions and gas content in the US

options.label: B
options.text: To ban burning coal in certain areas of London

title: The amazing ways plants defend themselves - Valentin Hammoudi

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary function of the waxy cuticle on plant leaves?

options.label: A
options.text: To absorb water and nutrients from the soil

multiple-choice.question: Which plant species produces microscopic needle-shaped crystals called raphides?

options.label: A
options.text: Spinach, kiwi fruit, pineapple, fuchsia, and rhubarb

multiple-choice.question: What is the purpose of the mechanoreceptor cells in the mimosa plant?

options.label: B
options.text: To absorb water and nutrients from the soil

options.label: D
options.text: To detect and respond to touch

multiple-choice.question: How do plants typically respond to an infection by microbes?

options.label: B
options.text: By thickening the waxy cuticle and strengthening cell walls

options.label: C
options.text: By sealing up pores in the leaves with guard cells

multiple-choice.question: What is the function of the compounds produced by plants in response to an infection?

options.label: C
options.text: To prevent more pathogens from making their way inside

multiple-choice.question: Which plant species releases a specific cocktail of chemicals to attract parasitic wasps?
What is the primary defense mechanism of the stinging nettle plant?

options.label: B
options.text: To produce microscopic needle-shaped crystals called raphides

options.label: C
options.text: To release a mixture of histamine and other toxins

multiple-choice.question: How do plants typically communicate with each other in response to an attack?
What is the function of the lignin in tree trunks?

options.label: D
options.text: To absorb water and nutrients from the soil

multiple-choice.question: How do plants typically respond to a threat from a large herbivore?

options.label: B
options.text: By sealing up pores in the leaves with guard cells

options.label: C
options.text: By thickening the waxy cuticle and strengthening cell walls

options.label: D
options.text: By using thorns, spines, and prickles

title: How does impeachment work? - Alex Gendler

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary purpose of impeachment in the United States?

options.label: A
options.text: To formally accuse a government official of wrongdoing, launching a trial

options.label: B
options.text: To punish a government official for past mistakes

options.label: C
options.text: To grant a government official immunity from prosecution

options.label: D
options.text: To remove a government official from office without due process

multiple-choice.question: Which of the following is a key difference between impeachment in the United Kingdom and the United States?

options.label: A
options.text: Impeachment in the UK is only used for treason, while in the US it is used for bribery and other high crimes

options.label: B
options.text: Impeachment in the UK is only used for elected officials, while in the US it is used for all civil officers

options.label: C
options.text: Impeachment in the UK is initiated by the monarch, while in the US it is initiated by the House of Representatives

options.label: D
options.text: Impeachment in the UK is a simpler process than in the US

multiple-choice.question: What is the role of the House Committee on Rules and the House Committee on the Judiciary in the impeachment process?

options.label: A
options.text: They conduct the trial and deliberation

options.label: B
options.text: They review the accusations and examine the evidence

options.label: C
options.text: They hold a separate vote on each of the specific charges

options.label: D
options.text: They are responsible for the prosecution

multiple-choice.question: What is the threshold for a conviction in an impeachment trial?

options.label: D
options.text: A majority of the House of Representatives

multiple-choice.question: What is the consequence of a conviction in an impeachment trial?

options.label: B
options.text: Disqualification from holding office in the future

options.label: C
options.text: Automatic removal from office and disqualification from holding office in the future

multiple-choice.question: What is the purpose of the Articles of Impeachment?

options.label: A
options.text: To formally accuse a government official of wrongdoing

options.label: B
options.text: To hold a separate vote on each of the specific charges

options.label: C
options.text: To conduct the trial and deliberation

options.label: D
options.text: To punish a government official for past mistakes

multiple-choice.question: Who presides over an impeachment trial if the president or vice president is being impeached?

options.label: B
options.text: The Chief Justice of the Supreme Court

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary purpose of impeachment in the US government?

options.label: A
options.text: To remove a government official from office

options.label: B
options.text: To formally accuse a government official of wrongdoing

options.label: D
options.text: To punish a government official for past mistakes

multiple-choice.question: What is the process for impeaching a government official in the US?

options.label: A
options.text: The House of Representatives initiates the process by referring the matter to a committee

options.label: B
options.text: The Senate initiates the process by holding a trial

options.label: C
options.text: The President initiates the process by removing the official from office

options.label: D
options.text: The Supreme Court initiates the process by hearing the case

multiple-choice.question: What is the significance of the Watergate scandal in the context of impeachment?

options.label: A
options.text: It was the first impeachment trial in US history

options.label: B
options.text: It led to the resignation of President Richard Nixon

options.label: C
options.text: It resulted in the conviction of President Nixon

options.label: D
options.text: It was a major factor in the passage of the 25th Amendment

title: Cell membranes are way more complicated than you think - Nazzy Pakpour

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary component of the fluid mosaic that makes up the cell membrane?
What is the structure of the phospholipid molecule?

options.label: C
options.text: Both head and tail are polar

options.label: D
options.text: Both head and tail are non-polar

multiple-choice.question: What is the function of cholesterol in the cell membrane?

options.label: A
options.text: To regulate the movement of molecules in and out of the cell

options.label: B
options.text: To keep the membrane at the right fluidity

options.label: C
options.text: To provide structural support to the cell

options.label: D
options.text: To protect the cell from external damage

multiple-choice.question: What is the process by which cells take in substances from the outside?
What is the function of transmembrane proteins in the cell membrane?

options.label: A
options.text: To anchor the membrane to the cell's interior scaffolding

options.label: B
options.text: To create channels that allow specific molecules through

options.label: D
options.text: To regulate the movement of molecules in and out of the cell

multiple-choice.question: What is the role of peripheral proteins in the cell membrane?

options.label: A
options.text: To provide structural support to the cell

options.label: B
options.text: To anchor the membrane to the cell's interior scaffolding

options.label: C
options.text: To regulate the movement of molecules in and out of the cell

options.label: A
options.text: To provide structural support to the cell

options.label: B
options.text: To regulate the movement of molecules in and out of the cell

options.label: C
options.text: To create channels that allow specific molecules through

options.label: D
options.text: To make all the functions of life possible

multiple-choice.question: What is the role of the cell membrane in the process of fertilization?

options.label: A
options.text: To prevent the sperm from fertilizing the egg

options.label: B
options.text: To facilitate the fusion of the sperm and egg membranes

options.label: C
options.text: To provide structural support to the fertilized egg

options.label: D
options.text: To regulate the movement of molecules in and out of the fertilized egg
